xml-rules.title: XML Syntax Rules
xml-rules.description: 6 rules that must be adhered to in order to create a valid XML file:

rule.heading: Rule 1: XML Documents Must Have a Root Element.
rule.description: Description: XML documents must contain one root element that is the parent of all other elements.

rule.heading: Rule 2: The XML prolog.
rule.description: Description: The XML prolog is optional. If it exists, it must come first in the document.

rule.heading: Rule 3: All XML Elements Must Have a Closing Tag.
rule.description: Description: In XML, it is illegal to omit the closing tag. All elements must have a closing tag.

rule.heading: Rule 4: XML Tags are Case Sensitive.
rule.description: Description: Opening and closing tags must be written with the same case.

rule.heading: Rule 5: XML Elements Must be Properly Nested.
rule.description: Description: In HTML, you might see improperly nested elements. In XML, all elements must be properly nested within each other.
rule.example: Code Sample: This text is bold and italic

rule.heading: Rule 6: XML Attribute Values Must Always be Quoted
rule.description: Description: XML elements can have attributes in name/value pairs just like in HTML. In XML, the attribute values must always be quoted.
